title-group.article-title: Descriptions of two new Species of Goniozus Förster, 1856 (Hymenoptera: Bethylidae) associated with insect induced plant galls from India

sec.p: Descriptions of two new Species of Goniozus Förster, 1856 ( Hymenoptera : Bethylidae ) associated with insect induced plant galls from India

SHREEVIHAR SANTHOSH 1 & AVINJIKKATTU PARAMBIL RANJITH
Department of Zoology, Malabar Christian College, Kozhikode (Affiliated to University of Calicut ), 673001 , Kerala, India . E-mail: nairssanthosh@gmail.com; ridhuranjith@gmail.com
1Corresponding author. E-mail: nairssanthosh@gmail.com

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Two new species of the genus Goniozus viz., Goniozus inauditus Santhosh
sp. nov. and G. kuriani Santhosh
sp. nov. associated with insect induced plant galls from South India are described. The parasitic relationship of Goniozus with the nonlepidopteran hosts living in the concealed habitats and their association with insect induced plant galls and its inhabitants are reviewed. The possible host range extension of Goniozus is commented.
Key words:Goniozus , plant galls, nonlepidopteran hosts, South India .

sec.title: Introduction
Material and methods
sec.p:
Leaf galls of Memecylon umbellatum Burm.
f. (
A) (The Plant List 2015 ) and Syzygium cumini (L.) Skeels (
B) were collected from Sowpnabitta (Karnataka) and Trivandrum (Kerala) respectively. The galls were identified by using
Mani ( 2000 )
and reared in 1000 ml glass beakers for the possible emergence of parasitoids.

The terms for integument sculpture follow
Harris ( 1979 )
and most of measurements and morphological terms adopted in this paper follow
Evans ( 1964 )
and
Terayama ( 2006 )
and the abbreviation as follows: AOL, anteroposterior ocellar line; DAO , maximum diameter of anterior ocelli; EV, post-orbital distance measured as distance from top of eye to posterior margin of vertex, measured in lateral view; F 1 , F 2 and F 11 , funicular segments 1, 2 and 11 respectively; FWL, maximum length of fore wing; HE, maximum length of eye in lateral view; LH, maximum length of head from clypeal margin to vertex in full dorsal view; M, median vein; OOL, ocello-ocular line; POL, posterior-ocellar line; WF, minimum distance between the eyes in full dorsal view; WH, maximum width of head including eyes in full dorsal view; WOT, width of ocellar triangle; SI, profemur sphericity index; VRN, Voucher Number.

Profemur Sphericity Index is calculated using the formula SI = (Profemur Length X Profemur Width)/ (Profemur Height) 2 to indicate the overall three-dimensional shape of the profemur (
Aguiar 2001 ), where the value 1 indicates a perfect sphere and the increasingly greater values indicate an elongated flattened or compressed profemur. Images were obtained using Leica S 8 APO attached to a Leica DFC 295 digital camera captured using Leica LAS (Leica Application Suite V 4.2 ) Microsystems by Leica (Heerburg, Switzerland ). Image stacks were combined into a single image using Leica Automontage Software V 4.2 . All examined specimens, including type material, are deposited in the Zoological Survey of India , Kozhikode ( ZSIK ).

Discussion . Goniozus kuriani sp. nov. is closely related to G. valvolicola Krombein
reported from Sri Lanka in having vertex emarginate, scrobe ecarinate, M, SM sparsely setose, posterior ocelli equal to or more than 0.5 × its diameter away from vertex margin and EV 0.75–0.85 × HE. Goniozus kuriani sp. nov. differs from G. valvolicola Krombein
in having ocellar triangle acute, forefemur 1.92 × as long as wide, OOL 0.66 × WOT, clypeal apical margin weakly produced and obtuse, anteromedian rectangular smooth propodeal area, but not elevated and pedicel longer than F 1 , whereas in G. valvolicola ocellar triangle in right angle, forefemur 2.07 × as long as wide, OOL 1.54–1.58 × WOT, clypeal apical margin strongly produced, acute, antero-median triangular smooth propodeal area is elevated and pedicel is shorter than F 1 .

Generally Goniozus species are relatively generalists in host-parasitoid association. Many of them are gregarious parasitoids of larval Lepidoptera . However, there are a few anomalous or questionable host records of Goniozus .
Nagy ( 1976 )
reported Goniozus gallicolla (Kieffer)
and G. plugarui Nagy
attacking pupae of their lepidopteran hosts, but the ‘pupal parasite’ might be the parasitoids reared from larvae after it had spun the cocoon and not yet pupated (
Polaszek & Krombein 1994 ). Apart from the lepidopteran hosts, the species Goniozus exhibit an extended host association as they were reared from Coleoptera .
Richards ( 1956 )
reported a tentatively identified G. g e s t ro i (Keiffer) reared from larvae of an anobiid beetle, Lasioderma sp. This is similar to most of the lepidopteran host associations of Goniozus ,
where the hosts share a moderate degree of concealment. The present study supports this.

The new species G. inauditus sp. nov. was reared from Crotonothrips sp. induced leaf galls of Memecylon umbellatum and this new species is found to be associated with Carpelimus sp. as gall inhabitants. Goniozus inauditus sp. nov. might have a parasitic association with the staphylinid as there is one authentic record of a coleopteran host ( Anobiidae ) for Goniozus by
Richards ( 1956 )
. Goniozus kuriani sp. nov. was emerged from the leaf galls induced by Trioza jambolanae Crawford
( Hemiptera : Triozidae ).
Gordh & Móczár ( 1990 )
listed six species of Goniozus associated with plant galls and its inhabitants, many of them were reared from cynipid galls.
Dohanian ( 1942 )
reported that an undetermined Goniozus sp. reared from the leaf galls induced by Cynips maculipennis (Gillette)
( Hymenoptera : Cynipidae ) on Quercus garryana Douglas ex Hook
( Fagaceae ). This host association needs to be verified as the galls were infested by filbert worm, Cydia (= Melissopus ) latiferreanus (Wlsm.) ( Lepidoptera : Totricidae) very shortly after the primary gall development.

The host-parasitoid interaction of G. microstigmi (
Melo & Evans 1993 )
could be the association of Goniozus with thrips as Microstigmus spp. act as a predator of the thysanopterans (
Polaszek & Krombein 1994 ). Association between G. inauditus sp. nov. and Carpelimus sp. strongly supports the chances for a parasitc relationship between the bethylid and the staphylinid as the species of Carpelimus exhibit a predatory behaviour with other organisms. There are association of Goniozus spp. with the gall community, which demands critical verification like that of Kurian’s ( 1952 ) report of G. morindae Kurian
associated with Asphondylia morindae Mani
( Diptera : Cecidomyiidae ), induces flower galls on Morinda tinctoria ( Rubiaceae ). There is a strong possibility for Goniozus spp. to attack the hosts living in a concealed habitat like plant galls, leaf fold and tree barks etc. apart from Lepidoptera and Coleoptera . This study concludes that the association of bethylids, particularly Goniozus spp. with the other members of the gall community, can modify the results of the selective pressure exhibited by the parasitoids on gall inhabitants.

Colour. Body black, abdomen dark brown; mandible black, teeth brown; antenna yellow, terminal five segments brown, last being darkest; legs yellow; coxae, femora with dorsal margin brown, wing hyaline, subcosta, prostigma, pterostigma brown, others veins colourless.

Head. Head longer than wide (
C), WH 0.81 × LH; 2 × as long as wide in lateral aspect; sides behind eye are parallel before curving inwards to slightly emarginated vertex; frons and vertex coriaceous with scattered shallow punctures (
C); gena smooth and polished (
B); vestiture short, sparse, suberect; setae on vertex not distinctly longer than setae on rest of head, longest being 0.068 mm ; anterior clypeal margin weakly produced, obtuse; clypeal carina strong and weakly arcuate in profile, extending onto front as a low carina up to level of posterior scrobal margin; scrobe ecarinate; mandible robust, four teeth, ventral most straight longest teeth; WF 0.48 × LH; WF = HE; EV 0.83 × HE; LH 2.3 × HE; malar space distinct; malar groove present; eye sparsely setose, setae minute, shorter than diameter of single facet; ocelli in acute triangle; posterior ocelli separated from vertex margin by half its diameter; OOL 0.67 × WOT; POL: AOL: DAO = 3.5 : 2 : 1.8 ; vertex smoothly curved to occiput, ecarinate; relative lengths of first five antennal segments are in the ratio of about 6 : 3 : 2.3 : 2.3 : 2.7 ; scape 1.33 × as long as wide, 2 × as long as pedicel; pedicel longer than F 1 ; all segments wider than long except terminal single segment; antenna slightly shorter than head in full dorsal view ( 27 : 29 ) (
C).

Mesosoma. Pronotum, mesonotum, and scutellum uniformly coriaceous, with scattered shallow punctures (
D); vestiture short, sparse, decumbent; pronotal disc 0.52 × as long as wide; mesonotum with complete parapsidal furrow, notauli absent; scutellum with a pair of basal pits at base connected by a narrow transverse groove, propodeal disc 0.53 × as long as wide, smoothly inclined to lateral margin (
D); basal median propodeal triangle absent, median smooth band, not elevated, extending beyond posterior margin of propodeal disc (
D); rest of propodeal disc, declivity coriaceous; posterior transverse propodeal carina broadly interrupted medially; forewing 2.88 × as long as wide; areolet present (
F); vein M, SM with single row of setae; areolet and speculum sparsely setose; profemur 1.92 × as long as wide; SI 7.67 .

Metasoma. Tergites smooth and polished, T 1 –T 3 with few setae restricted to lateral margin; other tergites sparsely setose all across dorsal side; metasoma distinctly longer than mesosoma ( 54 : 40 ), shorter than head plus mesosoma ( 54 : 67 ) (
A).
Male . Unknown.

Ecology and Biology . Ex. unidentified leaf galls of Syzygium cumini (L.) Skeels ( Myrtaceae ). The species is also collected from the plant host, Dipterocarpus indicus Bedd.
( Dipterocarpaceae ).
Etymology . The species epithet is after Chandy Kurian, who worked on Indian Bethylidae during 1952–1955 .
Distribution . India (Karnataka; Kerala).
Variation . In paratypes , OOL 0.62 × WOT and EV 0.72 × HE. See table 2 for the morphometric ratios of the type material examined.

Discussion . Goniozus kuriani sp. nov. is closely related to G. valvolicola Krombein
reported from Sri Lanka in having vertex emarginate, scrobe ecarinate, M, SM sparsely setose, posterior ocelli equal to or more than 0.5 × its diameter away from vertex margin and EV 0.75–0.85 × HE. Goniozus kuriani sp. nov. differs from G. valvolicola Krombein
in having ocellar triangle acute, forefemur 1.92 × as long as wide, OOL 0.66 × WOT, clypeal apical margin weakly produced and obtuse, anteromedian rectangular smooth propodeal area, but not elevated and pedicel longer than F 1 , whereas in G. valvolicola ocellar triangle in right angle, forefemur 2.07 × as long as wide, OOL 1.54–1.58 × WOT, clypeal apical margin strongly produced, acute, antero-median triangular smooth propodeal area is elevated and pedicel is shorter than F 1 .

Generally Goniozus species are relatively generalists in host-parasitoid association. Many of them are gregarious parasitoids of larval Lepidoptera . However, there are a few anomalous or questionable host records of Goniozus .
Nagy ( 1976 )
reported Goniozus gallicolla (Kieffer)
and G. plugarui Nagy
attacking pupae of their lepidopteran hosts, but the ‘pupal parasite’ might be the parasitoids reared from larvae after it had spun the cocoon and not yet pupated (
Polaszek & Krombein 1994 ). Apart from the lepidopteran hosts, the species Goniozus exhibit an extended host association as they were reared from Coleoptera .
Richards ( 1956 )
reported a tentatively identified G. g e s t ro i (Keiffer) reared from larvae of an anobiid beetle, Lasioderma sp. This is similar to most of the lepidopteran host associations of Goniozus ,
where the hosts share a moderate degree of concealment. The present study supports this.

The new species G. inauditus sp. nov. was reared from Crotonothrips sp. induced leaf galls of Memecylon umbellatum and this new species is found to be associated with Carpelimus sp. as gall inhabitants. Goniozus inauditus sp. nov. might have a parasitic association with the staphylinid as there is one authentic record of a coleopteran host ( Anobiidae ) for Goniozus by
Richards ( 1956 )
. Goniozus kuriani sp. nov. was emerged from the leaf galls induced by Trioza jambolanae Crawford
( Hemiptera : Triozidae ).
Gordh & Móczár ( 1990 )
listed six species of Goniozus associated with plant galls and its inhabitants, many of them were reared from cynipid galls.
Dohanian ( 1942 )
reported that an undetermined Goniozus sp. reared from the leaf galls induced by Cynips maculipennis (Gillette)
( Hymenoptera : Cynipidae ) on Quercus garryana Douglas ex Hook
( Fagaceae ). This host association needs to be verified as the galls were infested by filbert worm, Cydia (= Melissopus ) latiferreanus (Wlsm.) ( Lepidoptera : Totricidae) very shortly after the primary gall development.

The host-parasitoid interaction of G. microstigmi (
Melo & Evans 1993 )
could be the association of Goniozus with thrips as Microstigmus spp. act as a predator of the thysanopterans (
Polaszek & Krombein 1994 ). Association between G. inauditus sp. nov. and Carpelimus sp. strongly supports the chances for a parasitc relationship between the bethylid and the staphylinid as the species of Carpelimus exhibit a predatory behaviour with other organisms. There are association of Goniozus spp. with the gall community, which demands critical verification like that of Kurian’s ( 1952 ) report of G. morindae Kurian
associated with Asphondylia morindae Mani
( Diptera : Cecidomyiidae ), induces flower galls on Morinda tinctoria ( Rubiaceae ). There is a strong possibility for Goniozus spp. to attack the hosts living in a concealed habitat like plant galls, leaf fold and tree barks etc. apart from Lepidoptera and Coleoptera . This study concludes that the association of bethylids, particularly Goniozus spp. with the other members of the gall community, can modify the results of the selective pressure exhibited by the parasitoids on gall inhabitants.
